hints_html:
A shortcut solution is obtained by noticing that this is the definition of the derivative for a certain function at \(x=3\). What is this function?

We could also solve this by multiplying the numerator and the denominator by the conjugate of the numerator, i.e., \(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}\).
hints_latex:
A shortcut solution is obtained by noticing that this is the
\emph{definition of the derivative} for a certain function at $x=3$.
What is this function?

We could also solve this by multiplying the numerator and the
denominator by the \emph{conjugate} of the numerator, i.e.,
$\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}$.
hints_raw:
A shortcut solution is obtained by noticing that this is the ''definition of the derivative'' for a certain function at <math>x=3 </math>. What is this function?
We could also solve this by multiplying the numerator and the denominator by the ''conjugate'' of the numerator, i.e., <math> \sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3} </math>.
question: B 05
sols_html:
Recall that the definition of the derivative of a function f at x is

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) := \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\end{aligned}\]

Following hint 1, we see that if \(\displaystyle x = 3\) and \(f(x) = \sqrt{x}\), then

\[\begin{aligned} f'(3) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt3}{h} = L \\ L &= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}}\end{aligned}\]

The slower solution uses hint 2 and multiplies the numerator and the denominator by the conjugate of the numerator

\[\begin{aligned} L &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt{3}}{h}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt{3}}{h}\cdot \frac{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{3+h - 3}{h(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3})}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{h}{h(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3})}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{1}{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}\\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{3}}\\ &= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The slower solution uses hint 2 and multiplies the numerator and the
denominator by the conjugate of the numerator

\begin{align*}
L &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt{3}}{h}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt{3}}{h}\cdot \frac{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{3+h - 3}{h(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3})}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{h}{h(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3})}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{1}{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}\\
&= \frac{1}{\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{3}}\\
&= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Recall that the definition of the derivative of a function ''f'' at ''x'' is

:<math>f'(x) := \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}</math>

Following hint 1, we see that if <math>\displaystyle x = 3</math> and <math>f(x) = \sqrt{x}</math>, then

:<math>
\begin{align}
f'(3) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt3}{h} = L \\
L &= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}}
\end{align}
</math>
The slower solution uses hint 2 and multiplies the numerator and the denominator by the conjugate of the numerator

<math>
\begin{align}
L &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt{3}}{h}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\sqrt{3+h} - \sqrt{3}}{h}\cdot \frac{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{3+h - 3}{h(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3})}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{h}{h(\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3})}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{1}{\sqrt{3+h} + \sqrt{3}}\\
&= \frac{1}{\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{3}}\\
&= {\color{blue} \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}}
\end{align}
</math>
